Name: loudoun_2008_geology_fault_line
Originator: USGS Eastern Earth Surface Processes Team
OriginatorSort: USGS Eastern Earth Surface Processes Team
Abstract:
"Fault" is one of four layers which collectively describe the subsurface geologic formation, structural geology and surficial deposits.  "Fault" is the comprehensive mapping of geologic faults.

The geology of Loudoun County, Virginia, was mapped in 1988 through 1991 under a cooperative agreement between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the Loudoun County Department of Environmental Resources. This geologic map was compiled in 1993 from a series of detailed published and unpublished field investigations at scales of 1:12,000 and 1:24,000. Some of these same data were compiled as a digital geologic map at 1:100,000 scale (Burton and others, 1992a) and were the basis for a cost-benefit analysis of the societal value of geologic maps (Bernknopf and others, 1993).

The data was later revised and published by USGS in the Open File Report, MAP OF-99-150, GEOLOGIC MAP OF LOUDOUN COUNTY, VIRGINIA By Scott Southworth, W.C. Burton, J.S. Schindler, and A.J. Froelich1 with contributions on the geology of the Piedmont province by A.A. Drake, Jr., and R.E. Weems and an aeromagnetic survey by D.L. Daniels, W.F. Hanna, and R.E. Bracken.

    <descript>
      <abstract>"Fault" is one of four layers which collectively describe the subsurface geologic formation, structural geology and surficial deposits.  "Fault" is the comprehensive mapping of geologic faults.

The geology of Loudoun County, Virginia, was mapped in 1988 through 1991 under a cooperative agreement between the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the Loudoun County Department of Environmental Resources. This geologic map was compiled in 1993 from a series of detailed published and unpublished field investigations at scales of 1:12,000 and 1:24,000. Some of these same data were compiled as a digital geologic map at 1:100,000 scale (Burton and others, 1992a) and were the basis for a cost-benefit analysis of the societal value of geologic maps (Bernknopf and others, 1993).

The data was later revised and published by USGS in the Open File Report, MAP OF-99-150, GEOLOGIC MAP OF LOUDOUN COUNTY, VIRGINIA By Scott Southworth, W.C. Burton, J.S. Schindler, and A.J. Froelich1 with contributions on the geology of the Piedmont province by A.A. Drake, Jr., and R.E. Weems and an aeromagnetic survey by D.L. Daniels, W.F. Hanna, and R.E. Bracken.</abstract>
      <purpose>Geology was researched and compiled for use in studies of soils and groundwater, and to support the County's water resources plan.</purpose>
      <supplinf>Data are published by USGS at http://geology.er.usgs.gov/eespteam/GISLab/Search/Virginia/loudoun/index.html Files are available as ESRI shapefile and .e00 files. Data were originally prepared in Lat/Long (NAD27) and have been reprojected by the County to Virginia State Plane (North), Zone 4501, NAD83 HARN, US Feet. Data are stored in the corporate ArcSDE Geodatabase as a line feature class.  

For additional information, please see the geology supplements: 
    GEOLOGIC MAP OF LOUDOUN COUNTY, VIRGINIA
    REPORT TO ACCOMPANY MAP OF-99-150
    U.S. DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY 
    Southworth, et. al. (1999)
          and
    Interpretive Guide to Geology and Groundwater in Loudoun County, VA
    Loudoun County, VA, Dept. of Environmental Resources (1993)</supplinf>
    </descript>

      <procstep>
        <procdesc>USGS provide ESRI shapefiles in latitude and longitude decimal degrees and .e00 files are in UTM 18 NAD83.  Using ArcToolBox, the .e00 files were projected to Virginia State Plane North, HARN, US Survey feet using the Virginia HARN correction.  This was done in two-step process.  First projection is from UTM to NAD 83 and then from NAD83 to HARN.</procdesc>
        <procdate>2006</procdate>
        <proccont>
          <cntinfo>
            <cntorgp>

        <procdate>20061116</procdate>

The names were obtained from the recently published 2006 USGS Geologic Investigations Series Map I-2553, revised 2007.</procdesc>

      <eaover>FA_TYPE_HP: Type of Fault</eaover>
      <eadetcit>Type      Definition     

2            Thrust
3            Normal
4            Reactivated
5            Strike Slip
6            Overturned Anticline
8            Overturned Syncline
9            Synformal Anticline
10          Antiformal Syncline</eadetcit>
